Award.AwardTitle: Environmental Health Governance in Six Cities: How Scientific Cultures, Practices and Infrastructure Shape Governance Styles

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Audience Summary

This project will focus on efforts to understand and address the health effects of long term exposure to transportation-related air pollution in six cities: Albany, New York City, Philadelphia, Houston, Beijing, and Bengalura. In each city studied, project researchers will examine the operation and use of science in four arenas of governance: environment, health, transportation and education. They will explore how these different arenas interrelate, and they will map the sources of scientific evidence used in governance, how these sources are evaluated, and translated into policy and programming. They will also document and analyze the scientific infrastructures that produced the findings used in governance, the diversity of stakeholders involved in interpreting scientific findings, and diverse cultural logics that shape the creation and use of scientific knowledge in different settings. Ethnographic interviews will be the primary means of data collection, supplemented by analyses of scientific publications, policy debates, and media coverage. The final stage of the project will result in recommendations that will be actively disseminated among policy makers, journalists and other stakeholders in all cities and countries studied in the project. Project results will also be translated into curriculum for K-undergraduate students, using the techniques and infrastructure developed by RPI's EcoEd Research Group.

Technical Summary

This project is an innovative extension of an ongoing project, The Asthma Files project. The digital platform built for the ongoing project will support collaboration among researchers (including student researchers) involved in the new project. In addition, there will be in each city a field school to teach the project's methods to students. The aim of the project is to advance understanding of different ways scientific capacity is developed and used in governance, examining how environmental health research and governance has developed. The project will result in a theoretically robust, empirically grounded conception of environmental health research and governance styles, detailing and categorizing different ways of developing environmental health data, advancing the sciences of environment and health, and directing these toward governance of complex problems. It will extend theorization of governance by addressing how scientific cultures, practices, and infrastructure shape governance processes and outcomes; and it will test and stabilize the process and cyberinfrastructure needed to support collaborative research in the social studies of science. Project results will have wide implications in efforts to improve collaboration between governance regimes (across scale, and between nations); such collaboration is particularly important in addressing complex, often trans-boundary problems like air pollution, which call for new levels of cooperation and sharing of technology, data, and effective policy design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Air pollution has received escalating attention in recent years, with leading international bodies such as the World Health Organization (WHO) identifying air pollution as the world’s largest single environmental health risk. WHO now attributes one out of every eight global deaths to air pollution exposure, a staggering 7 million premature deaths in 2012 (WHO 2015). Understanding and governing air pollution, however, is remarkably complex and almost always controversial – because of tension between economic and environmental priorities, because environmental health stressors can be difficult to source and mitigate, because the science involved is multi-dimensional and difficult to translate into policy. Understanding and addressing air pollution thus requires extensive coordination among different scientific fields, among different government agencies and scales of government, and between educational, research, and government domains. The Environmental Health Governance in Six Cities Study (known as the 6+ Cities Study) works to characterize how this coordination happens in different cities, supporting comparative insight and cross-city dialogue.

NSF grant #1535888 initially funded research groups in each of six cities: Beijing, Bangalore, Houston, Philadelphia, New York City, and Albany.  The study was expanded to include four more Indian cities (Delhi, Hyderabad, Chennai and Pune, funded by the Azim Premji Foundation) and Los Angeles. Research groups based in each city – as well as researchers focused on themes across cities – are coordinated out of the University of California Irvine, Department of Anthropology by Professors Kim Fortun and Mike Fortun. Research in India is coordinated by Professor Aalok Khandekar at Indian Institute of Technology Hyderabad. 

This project has characterized distinctive styles of environmental health and risk governance at the city scale. Through interviews, observation of public events, and analysis of media, government, NGO, and scientific reports, the study team has examined different stakeholder roles and perspectives, linkages between policy domains (especially environment, transportation, health, and education), and links across scale (urban, state, national, and international). The project is theoretically grounded in historical and anthropological studies of the sciences that have characterized the “thought styles” of different scientific communities, and in a multidisciplinary social science literature on “governance” that accounts for  increasingly important ways non-state actors and processes shape how societies are regulated and change. Environmental issues such as air pollution and cities and their dynamics have all been key loci of attention in the governance literature, emphasizing the roles of NGOS and commercial enterprises as non-state actors. The 6+ Cities project has advanced theorization of governance through special attention to the role of scientific communities and organizations (including educational institutions) in governance processes.  

The project also had important methodological, research infrastructure, and educational dimensions. Methodologically, the study modeled and advanced capacity for multi-sited, internationally collaborative field research, which can be used to address a wide range of complex societal problems. The digital research infrastructure built for the project -- the Platform for Experimental, Collaborative Ethnography (PECE) -- is now freely available for download and use by other researchers (at https://pece-project.github.io/drupal-pece/). 

The project also built a digital archive of research material, much of it publicly accessible (at https://theasthmafiles.org/).  In this, the project refined and demonstrated good research data management for the qualitative social sciences.  Lessons learned have now been integrated into PhD training at the University of California Irvine, with supporting curriculum materials freely available for use by others (http://centerforethnography.org/content/experimental-ethnographic-methods-0/essay).  

The 6+ Cities Study’s broad impact also included air pollution-focused educational outreach at multiple levels.  Project researchers developed and delivered project-related education to elementary students, including air pollution-focused science, math and literature activities (https://theasthmafiles.org/content/ecoed/essay). Project researchers also integrated project results and shared its methodologies with undergraduate students in a newly designed, general education course at the University of California Irvine, “Environmental Injustice” (https://disaster-sts-network.org/content/environmental-injustice-fall-2019/essay). Numerous MA and PhD students also moved through the project, gaining collaborative research and professional development experience. 

This project borrows its name from the renowned “Harvard Six Cities Study,” which led to important air pollution legislation in the United States by linking air pollution (particularly PM 2.5) to health impacts.  The Harvard Six Cities study laid ground for the 6+ Cities in its multi-city approach, in its efforts to connect knowledge from different disciplines (including pollution sciences, health sciences, and economics), and in the way it shows how science moves into policy – often with considerable political pushback.  The 6+ Cities project aimed for similarly expansive intellectual merit and social impact. 

Contact: Professor Kim Fortun, kfortun@uci.edu (University of California Irvine Department of Anthropology).
